Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 03:32PM jenjan wrote: Thanks, wishiwere!  I did mean HT therapy.  Are you on HT therapy?  If so, have you had any side effects?  My mom lives 60 miles from me, but stayed with me after her surgery for 2 weeks.  She wanted to go home (although I prefer she stay with me) and I can hear in her voice that depression is setting in.  I talk to her every day at lunch and again in the evening and I keep pointing out the positives that she has going from a bad situation.  I know she is concerned about the side effects of chemo (if that is necessary), as well as the HT.  I have tried to absorb as much information as I can so I can pass it on to her accurately and I have told her about how wonderful this site is, so I certainly appreciate your input.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 07:55PM jenjan wrote: Thanks Beesie and Ginger.  I appreciate your guidance.  I will check out the link, Beesie.  From what I gathered on the info I saw, I thought the MX was a fairly good result at this time.  My mom had colon cancer 4 years ago, had surgery and no follow up treatment.  She has check ups every 6 moths, and so far, so good.  But, we did not have to look into treatments for that and there was no staging involved.  This has been a whole new ballgame when it comes to staging, treatment, etc.  My mom said she is going to donate her body to science since she has always had routine colonoscopies which were always negative and they found her colon cancer when she was in the hospital for pneumonia and anemia.  She has also had her yearly mammograms (the last being in 3/08) and they have all been reported as negative.  She just happened to find this lump by accident and her family doc and a local surgeon didn't think it was suspicious.  Come to find out, she had two separate malignant tumors in the same breast.  Go figure!  In any event, we have cried together and laughed together, so we will keep on that trend.  But again, I think having as much information as possible to make an intelligent decision about her treatment is the best thing we can do.  Thanks so much for all of your help.  I feel helpless at this point, so it is great for me to prepare her as much as I can.

Posts.Content: jenjan wrote: My mother (77 years old) has a mastectomy on 10/1/08 and we are scheduled for her first oncology visit on 10/23/08.  She was staged at T2, N0, MX.  I have not been able to determinen a concrete answer on the MX stage.  The best I understand is that the mets cannot be assessed.  Has anyone else had this staging?  I have been going over her path report to be prepared with questions for the onc and (needless to say) both of us are anxious about this appointment.  We understand from the surgeon that rad will not be done, chemo has a slight risk and most likely HRT will be recommended.  We are concerned about the MX part of the staging.  Anyone come across this?  If so, what did you learn about it?  Thanks!
